An under-reported demographic is that the median age of Ferguson black residents is only 28 while the median age of its white residents is 48. A significant percent of the city's black residents is too young to vote. Middle-age people turn out to vote n greater number than young people.

I think there is a local process involving being registered that discourages the poor, mostly black, citizens of Ferguson to participate. I don't think it is an overt or official process but one that has become part of the culture. Add to this a level of disenfranchisement from the political process and the result is the black community not voting and having a voice in their local government. And don't think for one minute that those in power are not interested in reducing black citizens from participating. Just see the comments by the Executive Director of the Missouri Republican Party, Matt Willis. Fortunately, other Republicans denounced his comments.

There is not much sense in arguing with the obsessed, but I will point out that Thomas failed to follow up on Schofield's victory at Franklin that reduced Hood's strength by at least a quarter and allowed Hood to dig in before Nashville. When he finally obeyed the direct order from Grant that he "attack Hood at once" nine days after he received it, he didn't destroy the army Hood commanded. The badly defeated Army of Tennessee got away because Thomas failed to adequately pursue it, a fault very common in federal generals. It finally was surrendered to Sherman by Johnston on April 26, more than four months later.

Grant's assessment of Thomas was probably quite accurate:
" He was a man of commanding appearance, slow and deliberate in speech and action; sensible, honest and brave. ... He gained the confidence of all who served under him, and almost their love. ... It is a quality which calls out the most efficient services of the troops serving under the commander possessing it. ...
"... He could not be driven from a point he was given to hold. He was not as good, however, in pursuit as he was in action. I do not believe that he could ever have conducted Sherman's army from Chattanooga to Atlanta against the defences and the commander guarding that line in 1864. On the other hand, if it had been given him to hold the line which Johnston tried to hold, neither that general nor Sherman, nor any other officer could have done it better."

The answer cannot lie "somewhere beyond the Pauls" because Ryan's answer  is not an answer to any question (except how do we make the rich richer). Ryan's program is also based on a non-economic world of zero sum games and money rather than real things. Krugman's "answers" correctly only address the current situation (the way economic solutions should always be), whereas Ryan have one size fits all situations: cut taxes, remove the safety net, and dilute regulations. You speak of demand and [thus] investment languishing, but the neo-classicals and austerians on other side are adamant that our problems are supply side in origin (to them, demand is never relevant in the long run).

Perhaps the austerians know neo-Keynesian bubbles always burst and are loath to replay the tech and housing catastrophes, certain that all those eased trillions are channeling through someone's casino and into risk-on assets. Equally certain are the Krugmanites that QE easing won't fire up inflation in the "age of oversupply," when powerful deflationary forces, emanating mostly from China, function to keep wages and prices as stagnant as the job market. The answer, it seems, lies somewhere beyond the Pauls (Ryan and Krugman). Yet, so long as one camp points to the obvious flaws in the other's policies, the layman is left confused by verbal battles in which the Pauls alternate setting alight their opponents straw person--PK torching the folly of austerity (Europe!), PR incinerating the folly of borrowing one's way out of a debt trap (Japan!).

But sometimes, Larry Summers, VOX, or even this column, injects the terrifying specter of "Secular Stagnation" into the mix, thus far without making the connection between radical global imbalances, and the tectonic structural changes facilitated by the era of "free trade." We're addicted to the hope that the Captains of Finance will continue to levitate the value of our 401Ks, pension funds, and provide the engine of growth to tug us out of our malaise--before those junk bonds, shaky sovereigns, and other risky assets implode. Meanwhile, wages, demand, and investment languish. Look to the heterodox.

I don't buy Krugman being over analytical lets him off the hook. A reason for economic malaise is left unidentified, and not because there is no rational answer. Krugman's confusion recalls his fascination with fairy tale corporate friendly Larry Summers bury my mistake secular stagnation cover story which ignores the Great Depression, Keynesian Economics, and the too small stimulus followed by austerity.

Yet I digress.

In a recession, layoffs are followed by a rise in productivity as those retaining employment pick up the slack. Profits rise. Since most work isn't physical anymore, and labor input to production is much smaller in modern times, this is much more easily accomplished. In a service economy one can replace the work of the 5% laid off by charging the same price for services. Rising profits increase asset prices too, hence record corporate profits and stock market.

The only threats to this come from
a) a robust economy, full employment, rising wage demands, calls for more equitable distribution of income
b) a Democratic dominated government buoyed by a healthy economy, strong recovery, susceptible to occasional lapses of very slightly progressive programs like Romneycare.

Austerity removes both.

If Krugman spoke to businessmen in Europe, he'd find out why austerity is so tolerated despite poor macro results. The masses suffer, but Other People Prosper. Who's down with OPP?

Also "Stupidity" is necessary to make the point, irony intended.

For me and most of the folks I know their pension is not indexed for inflation at all, i.e. it is fixed for life.  What PK and many other economists fail to consider is that lower interest rates is a twp edged sword.  While low rates can increase the price of existing assets and stimulate investment they also decrease consumption spending by significant parts of the public, e.g. those on a fixed income or living off their savings.  In addition they increase the required amount of savings required to fund a certain retirement income lower rates tend to increase desire savings for a lot of people.  Just check annuity rates & you will see that a lot more savings are required to achieve a given fixed annuity payment than 10+ years ago.  It does not appears that these factors are in the economic models, which assume that lower rates increase both investment and consumption.  These factors reduce the effective stimulus that results from lower rates, and do not seem to be appreciated by most economists.  This is part of the reason I do not favor the increase in inflation targets to ca 4-5%.  The other reason is because this seems like  theft from savers who have worked hard and saved only to have their savings eroded in an attempt to perhaps slightly boost the economy.  There are better ways to boost the economy, starting with eliminating the trade deficit, reducing income inequality, and increasing infrastructure investment.

Not sure about Luke W's point. Lee's army did indeed retreat on the 19th, after holding in place on the 18th as Lee sorted out the logistics of getting his army across the Potomac. There was no major slaughter of Union troops, because McClellan made no large scale effort to force a crossing.

McClellan might have destroyed the ANV on the 17th, and again on the 18th. Where Lee ended the 17th with no fresh troops except for a small, trailing brigade of AP Hill's division, McClellan had the entire VI Corps and most of the V Corps fresh at his disposal, and in position to deliver a crushing blow on the Rebel center, where the II Corps, at enormous cost, had by mid-day carried the Rebel line in the Sunken Road and occupied the high ground overlooking Sharpsburg.

Without any real feel for the ANV strength, however, McClellan dared not risk running into Lee's reserves, nonexistent as they were.

To Steve's point, Hooker certainly erred in failing to advance more aggressively in his flanking of the ANV (and then found himself outflanked the next day), and Meade might have done well to pursue the ANV more aggressively after Gettysburg. Neither, however, had as clear an opportunity to completely destroy the South's most important field army as McClellan did.

Perhaps 'fleeing' was not the right word in the context. But the fact of the matter, as recorded by historian James M McPherson, is that on the night of Sep 18 (1862), "the Army of Northern Virginia crossed the Potomac to its namesake state. Except for a feeble pursuit on the 19th and 20th that was easily repulsed, the Battle of Antietam was over. McClellan telegraphed news of a 'complete victory' to Washington. Forgotten was Lincoln's injunction to 'destroy the rebel army" ('Tried by War, pp. 125-126). Again, Lincoln visited the Army of the Potomac "in early October and urged McClellan to get moving before the Confederates could be reinforced.... Upon returning to Washington the President had Halleck send McClellan an order: ' Cross the Potomac and give battle ... Your army must move now while the roads are good. But McClellan as usual protested that he could not act until his supply wagons were full etc.... '" ('Battle Cry of Freedom', p.568).

Your points are well taken, but some contextual clarification is needed. Yes, Meade failed to press his advantage after Gettysburg, and Hooker, Burnside et al got their acts wrong. Neither these, nor McClellan's cold feet at Antietam were acts of treason. Actually, the adjective 'treasonous' was used by me in referring to M's reprehensible defiance of order to give aid to Pope in the 2nd Bull Run battle (reference to which had to be deleted from my original to stay within word limit). Lincoln told Hay of his suspicion: ''M  wanted Pope defeated''. 'Stanton wanted the man court-martialled. Chase said he should be shot. ('Tried by War', pp.120-121).

George B McClellan's loss in the 1864 Presidential election was caused as much by his ambivalence in collaborating with the anti-war 'copperhead' Democrats as by Sherman's big breakthrough at Atlanta paving the way to the ultimate Union victory. But he himself had serious limitations of character.
He was a vain man with a 'messiah complex'. He enjoyed being called the 'Young Napoleon' and relished his promotion as the general-in-chief (1861), which he gained by conspiring against Winfield Scott. His esteem for himself and lack of it for others showed in his letters to his wife, in which he called Scott an "imbecile" and the President: "the original gorilla, about as intelligent as ever." In his generalship, he was limited by an almost pathological fear of being outnumbered by the enemy, which led him always to justify inaction in battle by reporting inflated enemy strength. To his soldiers he posed as a 'populist' general, who wanted to avoid 'unnecessary' bloodshed. He was also a crypto-sympathiser of the slave-holders' rights and thought his job done if he could just defend the Union territories without going for the kill against Lee's Army. He squandered a great opportunity by not chasing the fleeing Southern army after Antietam. His only saving grace was as an organiser and battle trainer, which made Lincoln retain him after that 'treasonous' inaction for some more time. All in all, destiny served America well by not making him President.

The starving Bushman could have eaten the dogs. Yet the dogs were spared, and tolerated. The dogs had no usefulness in a society without land ownership or a need for collective hunting. For the white ranchers, on the other hand, dogs provided a tangible benefit. Dogs are excellent at sounding the alarm and protecting property. We can wax philosophical until we fall down exhausted, but at the end of the day the big difference in attitude seems to come down to utility. The author found in Dog a fellow traveler, who made him feel less alone. Utility, however sentimental it feels.
